Now, looking at the image content. The page is titled "Book II. ADVANCEMENT OF LEARNING." and page number 217. The content starts with "do not find the wisdom and diligence of Aristotle well pursued, who began to make a collection of the popular signs and colours of good and evil, both simple and comparative, which are as the sophisms of rhetoric, as I touched before. For example: [some example texts]". So it's a page discussing the history of learning, with examples of syllogisms, antithesis, etc.

Now, the task is to extract questions and answers from this page. The user says: "Je haalt studievragen uit een foto van een lesboek." So we need to find study questions (questions) and answers from the image.

Looking at the text, there's a section that says: "There remain two appendices touching the tradition of knowledge, the one critical, the other pedantic. For all knowledge is either delivered by teachers, or attained by men's proper endeavours; therefore as the principal part of tradition of knowledge concerneth chiefly writing of books, so the relative part thereof concerneth reading of books; wherein it is usually the true correction and edition of authors; wherein nevertheless rash diligence hath done great prejudice. For these critics have often presumed, that which they understand not is false set down: as the priest that, where he found it was written of St. Paul, "Demissus est per sportam," mended his book, and made it "Demissus est per portam;" because sporta was a hard word, and out of his reading; and surely their errors, though they be not so palpable and ridiculous, are yet of the same kind. And therefore, as it hath been wisely noted, the most corrected copies are commonly the least correct."

Then there are more sections talking about the defects of Aristotle, the exposition of authors, times, etc.

Looking at the text:

"ADVANCEMENT OF LEARNING. 217"

"do not find the wisdom and diligence of Aristotle well pursued, who began to make a collection of the popular signs and colours of good and evil, both simple and comparative, which are as the sophisms of rhetoric, as I touched before. For example:

SOPHISMA:
"Quod laudatur, bonum vituperatur, malum."
REDEAROTIO.
" Laudat venales qui vult extrudere merces.
Malum est, malum est, inquit emptor: sed cum recens- serit, tum gloriae."

The defects of Aristotle are three: one, that there be but a few of many; another, that their elenchs are not annexed; and the third, that for his use is not only in probation, but much more in impression. For many forms are equal in signification which are differing in impression; as the difference is great in the piercing of that which is sharp and that which is flat, though the strength of the percussion be the same; for there is no man but will be a little more raised by hearing it said, "Your enemies will be glad of this:" than by hearing it said only, "This is evil for you."

Secondly, I do resume also that which I mentioned before, touching provision or preparatory store, for the furniture of speech and readiness of invention, which appareth to be of two sorts; the one in resemblance to a shop of pieces unmade up, the other to a shop of things ready made up; both to be applied to that which is frequent and most in request; the former of these I will call antitheta, and the latter formula.

Antitheta are theses argued "pro et contra;" wherein men may be more large and laborious: but, in such as are able to do it, to avoid prolixity of entry, I wish the seeds of the several arguments to be cast up into some brief and acute sentences, not to be cited, but to be as skains or bottoms of thread, to be used; applying authorities and examples by reference.

PRO VERBIS LEG. "Non est interpretatio, sed divinatio, quae recedit, a litera: Cum recedit a litera, judex transit in legistorem."

PRO SENTENTIA LEG. "Ex omnibus verbis est eliciendus sensus, qui interpretatur singula."

Formulae are but decent and apt passages or conveyances of speech, which may serve indifferently for differing subjects; as of preface, conclusion, digression, transition, excusation, &c. For as in buildings, there is great pleasure and use in the well-casting of the staircases, entries, doors, windows, and the like; so in speech, the conveyances and passages are of special ornament and effect."

The page ends with "Vol. I.â€”28"
